add_url_rule method, which results in a different handler for each
addition. This was problematic when the same synchronous view function
is added multiple times for multiple routes as the handler would
differ for each addition and hence result in an overwrite assertion
error.

This commit solves the problem by knowing if a handler is in fact a
wrapper added by Quart and if so comparing against the wrapped view
function.

This makes the API more flexible and useable, which is required for

This adds initial support of ASGI, allowing ASGI servers such as
uvicorn and daphne to be used with Quart. To do so requires the Quart
instance (typically called ``app``) to be wrapped in a ASGIServer as so

    # main.py

    from quart.serving import ASGIServer

    app = Quart(__name__)
    ...
    asgi_app = ASGIServer(app)

and then uvicorn (and others) can be used via

    uvicorn main:asgi_app

Note that this is provisional, and I will likely change (or have to
change) this API.

Uvicorn has a real advantage in that it uses httptools rather than h11
to parse HTTP/1, which is quicker (although less robust). It has the
disadvantage that HTTP/2 is not supported.

This allows Quart to be used with an ASGI server to serve websocket

commit_description:
This is aimed to mitigate an attack whereby a client requests a route
that is known to stream a large amount of data e.g. a video, and stops
reading from its socket. This results in back-pressure to the Quart
server which would previously just continue to write to the socket and
fill in memory buffers. With enough connections and large enough
streaming responses this could exhaust the host memory and crash the
server.

To mitigate this the Quart Serving code now responds to the asyncio
pause_writing and resume_writing callbacks by clearing and setting an
awaitable event. This event can then be awaited (in a drain call)
during streaming, therefore preventing further writes till the back
pressure is reduced. This is similar to the undocumented
`_drain_helper` method on asyncio protocols.

The decorator must be used within a context, rather than outside of as
the previous documentation suggested.

The endpoint should be the second argument, before the view_func to
match the Flask API and expectations.

commit_title: Bugfix h2c upgrade process with request body
commit_description:
Requests with a body and h2c upgrade headers are a pain, as the body
must be fully received over HTTP/1.1 before the upgrade response is
sent, the connection is upgraded and the correct response sent via
HTTP/2. This is a pain as Quart can't both upgrade and wait for the
body.

As h2c is a niche use case (most HTTP/2 clients, including all
browsers don't support it), Quart will take the easy option and ignore
the upgrade header if a request has a body. Should a client really
want this, the client should send a pre-flight options request to
upgrade the connection and then send the actual request with the body.

If I read RFC 7230 correctly, invalid upgrade headers (or upgrade
headers in general) may be ignored by the server. Doing so seems to be
a better response that to just send a 400 error response.

flask_ext is a legacy Flask system for extensions, and hence using
this name suggests it is the same system rather than a system to
provide Flask imports via a patch of Quart. flask_patch is chosen with
hope that it communicates well that the point is to patch Quart to
provide flask imports. This name however loses the message that it is
worth doing only to support flask extensions.

These match the Flask API (aside from async, await) and allow for
object orientated based view code.
